title: Django Debug Mode Enabled - Sensitive Information Disclosure
description:
The Django application has DEBUG = True enabled in production settings. This causes sensitive information to be leaked to attackers through debug error pages. When accessing non-existent endpoints, triggering CSRF failures, or invalid HTTP methods, the application reveals:

1. Django version and framework information
2. Complete URL patterns and application routing structure
3. Application name: ssti_debug_art_gallery
4. Filesystem paths
5. Stack traces with code context (in case of exceptions)
6. Database configuration details (if exceptions occur)
7. SECRET_KEY exposure (if exception occurs during middleware processing)

Django's debug mode is designed for development only and should NEVER be enabled in production environments as it exposes critical security information.
impact: Attackers can gain significant information about the application architecture, which facilitates further exploitation. In particular, the application name (ssti_debug_art_gallery) suggests potential SSTI vulnerabilities may exist. Filesystem paths and framework details enable targeted attacks. If an exception occurs, the SECRET_KEY may be exposed, allowing session hijacking and CSRF token forging. The disclosure of URL patterns enables attackers to understand the application's routing structure and identify attack vectors.
evidence:
POC executed successfully confirming DEBUG mode exposure: Command executed: ``` ./poc_django_debug_mode_disclosure.sh ``` Results: - ✓ VULNERABILITY CONFIRMED: DEBUG = True is enabled - ✓ Application name 'ssti_debug_art_gallery' disclosed in URLconf reference - ✓ URL patterns exposed: accounts/, ^static/(?P.*)$ - ✓ Full request metadata visible in error page - ✓ Django error page returned 404 with detailed debugging information Response excerpt shows: ```

Using the URLconf defined in ssti_debug_art_gallery.urls, Django tried these URL patterns, in this order:

  1. accounts/
  3. ^static/(?P<path>.*)$
``` This confirms that accessing any non-existent endpoint (/nonexistent_endpoint_12345) returns the Django debug error page with complete application structure details.
remediation:
1. Set DEBUG = False in Django settings for production environment immediately
2. Configure proper ALLOWED_HOSTS setting with specific domain names
3. Set up proper logging to file instead of displaying debug pages to users
4. Use LOGGING configuration to capture errors securely for server-side analysis only
5. Create custom error templates (404.html, 500.html) that don't expose sensitive information
6. Use email alerts for errors instead of displaying them to users
7. Review settings.py for SECRET_KEY and other sensitive data, ensure SECRET_KEY is loaded from environment variables
8. Implement production-grade error handling that logs exceptions server-side without client exposure
9. Use Django security middleware including SecurityMiddleware to add security headers
10. Test all error pages thoroughly with DEBUG = False before deploying to production
references: CWE-200: Information Exposure (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/200.html), OWASP A01:2021 - Broken Access Control, OWASP A03:2021 - Injection, Django Security Documentation on DEBUG Setting (https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/stable/ref/settings/#debug), OWASP Top 10 Information Disclosure
toolCallDescription: Document Django DEBUG mode information disclosure vulnerability with confirmed working POC
